abstract.text: A high-level interface for manipulating image data.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You use instances of

to load existing images, create new images, and draw the resulting image data into your views. Although you use this class predominantly for image-related operations, the class itself knows little about the underlying image data. Instead, it works in conjunction with one or more image representation objects (subclasses of
) to manage and render the image data. For the most part, these interactions are transparent.
The  class serves many purposes, providing support for the following tasks:
Loading images stored on disk or at a specified URL.
Drawing images into a view or graphics context.
Providing the contents of a
object.
Creating new images based on a series of captured drawing commands.
Producing versions of the image in a different format.
The

class itself is capable of managing image data in a variety of formats. The specific list of formats is dependent on the version of the operating system but includes many standard formats such as TIFF, JPEG, GIF, PNG, and PDF among others. AppKit manages each format using a specific type of image representation object, whose job is to manage the actual image data. You can get a list of supported formats using the methods described in Determining Supported Types of Images.
For more information about how to use image objects in your app, see

content.text: Using Images with Core Animation Layers

inlineContent.text: Although you can assign an
object directly to the
property of a
object, doing so may not always yield the best results. Instead of using your image object, you can use the

method to obtain an object that you can use for your layer’s contents. The image created by that method serves as the contents of a layer, which also supports all of the layer’s gravity modes. By contrast, the
class supports only the
, and
modes.
Before calling the
method, use the

method to get the recommended scale factor for the resulting image. The code listing below shows a typical example that uses the scale factor of a window’s backing store as the desired scale factor. From that scale factor, the code gets the scale factor for the specified image object and creates an object that you assign to the layer. You might use this code for images that fit the layer bounds precisely or for which you rely on the
property of the layer to position or scale the image.

Describes how High Dynamic Range (HDR) image content displays.

Constants that describe the resizing mode for the image.
An object that contains the specific font, style, and weight attributes to apply to a symbol image.
The image’s accessibility description.
Adds the specified image representation object to the image.

Tests whether the image can create an instance of itself using pasteboard data.

The image’s delegate object.
Draws all or part of the image at the specified point in the current coordinate system.
Draws the image in the specified rectangle.
Draws all or part of the image in the specified rectangle in the current coordinate system.
Draws all or part of the image in the specified rectangle respecting the hints and the orientation of the current coordinate system.
Draws the image using the specified image representation object.
Returns whether the destination rectangle would intersect a non-transparent portion of the image.
Returns an array of UTI strings identifying the image types supported by the registered image representation objects, either directly or through a user-installed filter service.
Returns an array of UTI strings identifying the image types supported directly by the registered image representation objects.
Initializes and returns an image object using the specified URL.

Creates and returns an image object whose contents are drawn using the specified block.

Creates a symbol image with the system symbol name and variable value you specify.

A Boolean value that indicates whether it is possible to draw an image representation.

A Boolean value that indicates whether the image prefers to choose image representations using color-matching or resolution-matching.

abstract.text: An object that manages image-based content and allows you to perform animations on that content.
An object that provides the contents of the layer. Animatable.
A constant that specifies how the layer’s contents are positioned or scaled within its bounds.
The content is resized to fit the entire bounds rectangle.
The content is resized to fit the bounds rectangle, preserving the aspect of the content. If the content does not completely fill the bounds rectangle, the content is centered in the partial axis.
The content is resized to completely fill the bounds rectangle, while still preserving the aspect of the content. The content is centered in the axis it exceeds.
Create scalable images that integrate with your app’s text, and adjust the appearance of those images dynamically.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The protocol for implementing a class to allow an item provider to create an instance of the class.
The protocol for implementing a class to allow an item provider to retrieve data from an instance of the class.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A protocol that describes how a type interacts with transport APIs such as drag and drop or copy and paste.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
